utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: I was wondering if you could tell me a little bit about what brought you in.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, so like a couple months ago I was in the office and they told me that I have asthma like I had it when I was a little kid and I thought I grew out of it, but apparently not, or like it came back or something so. Yeah, so they just told me to come back today. I don't really have like any issues.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, So what what brought on the appointment in the summer time or a couple of months ago?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh. So like I have gym class at school and my teacher justalways thought that like should be able to run faster like I'm looking good athlete but I just couldn't go much faster and I was like saying I can't really breathe when I'm running that fast. And then you know my mom was like you should probably go. We should probably make an appointment.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and uh, when you're exercising or in gym class, do you get short of breath or do you find that you have difficulty breathing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah, like I will if I if I try to run fast. Like I, kinda can't breathe anymore. So I kind of stop or go slower.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how long does it take for the breathing difficulty to go away?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: If I stop doing like the thing I'm doing it, I I don't know not very long like couple of minutes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and uh, does this happen in any other settings?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh, like sometimes when it's really cold outside, I'll go out and like it. My chest feels tight and just feel like I can't breathe and kind of sucks like my girlfriend wanted to build a snowman and do snow Angels and stuff and I couldn't do it. Oh, another time, like I went to my friends house and they had like a bunch of cats I I felt like I got wheezy sound and I felt like that time it took longer for for the breathing to get easier like I had to leave.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so you've noticed changes to to your breathing sounds? Like you've had noisy breathing before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, mostly just with the cat.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: We don't have a cat at my house, so I didn't really think anything of it. And then I went to my friends house who had a bunch of cats and. Then at that time, I could actually hear it.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have you had a cough?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, And. Were there anything, was there anything that you tried besides the rest to make those symptoms go away?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Like I have the, uh um inhaler that the doctor gave me last time. So yeah, like I've been using it in gym class now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how many days per week are you using that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Well, I'm a little confused now because. I the 1 supposed to use, like every day a couple times, and then there was a different one that I thought it was only supposed to be used if the other one didn't work. But now the nurse just told me that I'm supposed to use them both, so I only got the one at the pharmacy so I don't really I don't really know. I feel like a bit confused now, but I always use the 1 supposed to be like 2 times a day, the one that starts with an "s", um but sometimes I just do it once a day if I forget the second one.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, well um we can definitely clarify the confusion about the medications today. Sometimes, for steroid medications, those ones are required to be used daily in order to get the maximal benefit, and so will take a look at your medications and see if one of those has a steroid component in it and say and how often you're needing it. Have you been having any episodes of shortness of breath at night time?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh no. No, mostly like gym class like I said.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And have you had any other associated symptoms?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh. I don't think so. Like what do you mean?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um, so anything like like allergies like runny nose or really itchy eyes with maybe some like um tearing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: When I was around the cats, yeah. But not the other times.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And do you ever have any rashes on your skin or or really itchy skin?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: When I was a kid but not really now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how about any nausea or vomiting?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Any infectious symptoms overall?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Ahh, I don't I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any urinary problems?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, like. No, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Bowel problems?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: uh no, no. No, that's all good.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK um. And, uh, any fevers or chills?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and then how about, uh, have you been having any night sweats?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: What's that?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: So, uh, overnight when you're sleeping you wake up with either your like pajamas drenched, or your your sheets drenched drenched from sweating.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um not that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. So I just wanted to ask a few questions about your past health. Have you been, so you mentioned asthma. Have you been diagnosed with any other medical conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no that's it.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, um, and any recent hospitalizations?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Like I broke my leg years ago but like that was just like really fast.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and any surgeries?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh. Just like my wisdom teeth.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and any medications besides it like that, including the inhalers?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nothing else, just. Just those things and my mom makes me take a vitamin.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and any allergies?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: What I don't know like not that I thought, but maybe like cats.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you have any like seasonal allergies? Do you find like in the spring or fall time or even summer that you get um like dry eyes or really itchy eyes or runny nose?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I just thought like I had a cold, but I guess like I usually feel like that in the springtime.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And, uh, are immunizations up to date?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I think so, like I've had all the stuff that I'm supposed to. I think I don't know the names of everything.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and so I actually wanted to ask a few questions about personal and kind of lifestyle habits. But first I was wondering if you could tell me a little bit about your living situation?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: You know, like I live with my mom and Dad and I like my little brother.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and um, where do you go to school?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um to to the. The school, um like high school down the road.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and in what grade now?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: And, I'm in Grade 11.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and what types of like hobbies or kind of activities are you interested in?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I like I like playing video games, I was really wanting to join the Marines and I was really trying to get into that stuff, but then I heard like you can't when you have asthma. Oh so I I kinda wanna know bout that like is that gonna stop me from doing that?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, so it's something that we will look into today. I'm. I'm not too sure what the details are regarding that information, but thank you for bringing that up and we'll be for sure to look into that together. And that reminded me of a question I wanted to ask earlier and so have you had pulmonary function tests done before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, what is that?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: So essentially they'll have you kind of breathing into a tube where you'll have periods where you'll maximally inhale and then maximally exhale as quickly as you can, and you'll do different types of breathing movements so that it gets measured on a on a device.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Is that like when you breathe in that the tube?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, exactly.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, like the last time I was here like couple months ago I did that and it said that, she said that my asthma was back.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Right, thank you for clarifying. And so, so for the last few questions about. And your personal habits. I was wondering. I understand that people in your age group might experience with smoking or or alcohol. Do any of your friends do that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I mean, sometimes we'll drink beer like at parties on the weekend. I don't, I don't drink a lot.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and can you tell me a little bit about your diet?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Sorry I missed that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Just wondering if you could tell me a little bit about your diet?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh, well my mom always like makes me a lunch like I'll have like a sandwich for lunch with like you know ham and cheese or something. I'll usually have like cereal for breakfast and my mom makes dinner. It's usually like meat like potatoes and vegetables or something. I think it's like pretty normal.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and are you currently sexually active?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh. Like I have a girlfriend. Just with her. Uh, like just recently. Yeah we started.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you use a condom?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Every time or sometimes?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh yeah, every time. It's not doing that many times, but yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, great and um have you had any other partners?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no like I had made out with other people before, but this is like the first one.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, but have you had a sexually transmitted infection before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and I know this question might seem a little bit invasive, but it's important to ask everybody. Have you had any thoughts of hurting or harming yourself?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No I haven't.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, great um. And in your family, has anybody ever had any of these similar symptoms before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Like may my dad, I think he maybe had asthma when he was younger, but like he doesn't really have it now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and any allergies that run in the family?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Mmmm, like my dad also really. Dad gets like a runny nose in the spring. So yeah, I think that's allergies.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. um. So overall, it's it's sounding like you been having this shortness of breath or difficulty breathing episodes that you're saying that it's made worse when you're exercising, out in the cold, and then around pets. And sometimes when the season changes as well and in the spring and so and then the recent diagnosis on pulmonary function tests a few months ago. So I think it would be important to clear up the medications today and try to get that better organized moving forward because it sounds like you're still pretty symptomatic with needing to use them daily currently. And so will look into that and then also the question about the Marines. Uh, interest with asthma.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, thank you. I really wanna know that like that was my plan and now I'm like kinda worried I can do that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Excellent.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
